section.title: Motivation
section.p: We begin with a few examples.

ul.li: The polynomial equation x^4 - 5x^2 + 4 = 0 has four solutions: x = 1, x = -1, x = 2, and x = -2.
The polynomial equation x^4 - 1 = 0 has two solutions: x = 1 and x = -1.
The polynomial equation x^4 + 1 = 0 has no solutions.

section.p: Solutions of a polynomial equation are called the roots of the equation, and are also often referred to as roots of the polynomial involved. From the examples above, different polynomials of the same degree can have different numbers of roots.

statement.p: What can we say about the possibilities for the number of roots a polynomial can have?

If p(x) is a polynomial of degree n \ge 1, then the polynomial equation p(x) = 0 has at most n roots, even when repeated roots are counted multiple times, according to the number of times that root is repeated.

proof.title: Proof idea
proof.p: A proper proof would use proof by induction, but we will be a little less formal. If the polynomial equation p(x) = 0 has no solutions at all, then clearly the number of solutions is not more than the degree n. On the other hand, if this equation has distinct solutions x_1,x_2,\dotsc,x_\ell, then it is a fact of algebra that we can factor p(x) as p(x) = (x-x_1)^{m_1} (x-x_1)^{m_2} \dotsm (x-x_\ell)^{m_\ell} q(x), where each exponent m_i is equal to the number of times solution x=x_i is repeated as a root of the equation (called the multiplicity of the root), and q(x) is another polynomial with no roots.

Since the degree of the factorization of p(x) above must be the same as the degree of p(x), the sum m_1 + m_2 + \dotsb + m_\ell cannot be greater than n, and this sum of multiplicities is exactly the number of roots of the equation p(x)=0 (including repetition).

section.p: In some sense, the optimal situation is when a polynomial has a full slate of roots (including repetition), so that the polynomial can be fully factored into linear terms. In order to fix the problem of some polynomials having fewer than a full slate of roots, we will just invent solutions for these root-deficient polynomials.
The quintessential example of a polynomial equation with no solution is x^2 + 1 = 0 . Let's start by inventing a solution to this equation.

note.p: Notice in particular that \ci^2 = -1, which will be the main way that we use the definition of \ci above in algebraic computations.

remark.p: It is common to think of \ci as being equal to \sqrt{-1}, because (\sqrt{-1})^2 + 1 = -1 + 1 = 0 suggests that if -1 had a square root, then it would be a solution to x^2+1=0, which is what's desired. However, the notation \sqrt{-1} implies that this is a positive square root, greater than zero. Where we're going, concepts of greater than and less than will no longer be meaningful.

section.p: If we want to treat this new imaginary number just like our ordinary real numbers that we're used to, we would like to be able to perform operations invovling it and other numbers, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and taking negatives. To do this, we will treat \ci algebraically as if it were a variable.

More on that in the next section. For now, let's just start with taking negatives. Since (-x)^2 = x^2 for every real number x, we will require the same of our new imaginary number: (-\ci)^2 = \ci^2. But then aSo if we stipulate that -\ci is not the same imaginary number as \ci (a reasonable requirement, since no nonzero real number is equal to its own negative), then with the invention of the imaginary number \ci, the polynomial equation x^2 + 1 = 0 now has just as many solutions as the degree of the polynomial involved!
In summary, in the example of the polynomial x^2 + 1, we can go from having no solutions to the full amount allowed by by inventing one solution.

section.title: The field of complex numbers
section.p: Now that we have a new number, let's let it out to play with all the other numbers.

statement.p:
Suppose we have polynomial x^2 - 6x + 13. Is the number 3+2\ci a root?
(3+2\ci)^2 - 6(3+2\ci) + b \amp = (9 + 12\ci + 4(-1)) - 18 - 12\ci + 13 \amp \amp (\ci^2 = -1)
\amp = 0.
The answer is yes! By algebraically combining \ci, which is a root of the prototypical unsolvable polynomial equation x^2+1, with other real numbers, we obtain roots of other previously unsolvable polynomial equations.

section.p: It turns out that the result of combining such expressions involving \ci using the four operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division can always be simplified using i^2 = -1 down to something of the form a + b\ci, where a,b are real numbers.

statement.p: The collection \C of all possible algebraic expressions a+b\ci, where a,b are real numbers. Expressions of this form are called complex numbers. In such an expression, the number a is called the real part and the number b is called the imaginary part.

ul.li: The complex number -3+\frac{1}{2}\ci has real part -3 and imaginary part \frac{1}{2}.
The complex number e - \pi\ci = e + (-\pi)\ci has real part e and imaginary part -\pi.

section.p: Here are examples of adding, subtracting, multiplying, and exponentiating complex numbers. (We will deal with division afterward.) Notice it mostly involves just familiar algebra: collecting like terms and FOIL.

The last in the list of examples above is particularly important. You may recognize it as related to the factorization of a difference of squares. Since \ci^2 = -1, multiplying a complex number against its difference-of-squares-factorization partner like this always results in a real number. Because of this, we'll give this partner a name.

statement.p: For complex number z = a + b\ci, we define the complex conjugate of z to be \cconj{z} = \lcconj{a+b\ci} = a - \b\ci.

remark.p: You should think of complex conjugate as flipping the sign on the imaginary part of the complex number. In particular, if z = a - b\ci, then \cconj{z} = \lcconj{a - b\ci} = a + b\ci.

section.p: Before we list some properties of the complex conjugate, we will use it to help us divide complex numbers.

statement.p:
The following are valid rules of algebra involving the complex conjugation operation involving complex numbers w and z and real number k.
\cconj{k} = k.
\lcconj{kz} = k\cconj{z}.
\lcconj{w+z} = \cconj{w} + \cconj{z}.
\lcconj{wz} = \cconj{w}\cconj{z}.
